instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PP5VS4 Short
threads.message:
Hey guys.

13" 2017 4 port, powering on and stuck at Apple logo on first inspection.

Discovered customer severed trackpad cable while attempting DIY battery replacement WITH BATTERY CONNECTED and fried L4500 (charcoal!).

Full short to ground on PP5VS4. I removed L4500 and cleaned/dug around the roasted section and all layers seem to be clean and seperate so I suspect the short is somewhere else.

Any suggestions on a likely culprit on this rail, any "usual suspects"?

Just thought I'd ask before I inject voltage on the line since Banjo (<CHIP>U7800</CHIP>) is on this rail and I don't want to fry him...

Cheers,

Mick

[ATTACH alt="Screen Shot 2020-07-29 at 5.23.32 pm.jpg"]59342[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PP5VS4 Short
threads.message:
So the short remains on pad 2 of L4500?
Very likely short between copper layers, underneath the pad.
Polish the edges of the hole, to eliminate any contact between layers.
You may need to dig a bit inside the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PP5VS4 Short
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 63004, member: 682"]
So the short remains on pad 2 of L4500?
Very likely short between copper layers, underneath the pad.
Polish the edges of the hole, to eliminate any contact between layers.
You may need to dig a bit inside the board.
[/QUOTE]

Yes correct, the short remains on pad 2.

I will try a cleaning up the hole little more. What technique/tool do you use to "polish" the edges as you put it?

threads.message:
